title: Do smartphones have a planned obsolescence built in, why? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is more complicated than a yes or no. The “why” part is simple and obvious. To sell more phones. If everyone needs a new phone every couple years, then the industry becomes way bigger. Now about that planned obsolescence; no not exactly. The hardware will be good to go for a long time; maybe just replace the battery every couple of years. I’m still on a Galaxy Note 4 that’s approaching 5 years now and it’s fine, my Galaxy S3 would be tolerable too. I’m not running the stock software though, I’ve used Lineage OS (a custom build of Android not from Samsung or Verizon) for a few years on those phones, and so I’m on the newest software on those phones! This goes to show; hardware can last a long time, though you might not be playing the latest games. I don’t game on my phone anyway so I don’t really care. So what goes bad? Well, the software. For starters, the phone stops getting OS updates after a couple years. Several reasons why this is terrible; main one being that you’re no longer getting virus protection and hackers can find new exploits that are no longer being patched after a couple years. Second problem is that after Android has moved on to a new version, developers tend to spend a lot less time updating their apps to work smoothly with an old OS. How is this planned obsolescence? Well it’s not exactly, that’s why I said it’s dodgy. Verizon (or your provider) stops updating a phone, and performance starts tanking immediately. Obviously, as I mentioned, we can load up a version of Android such as Lineage OS and get the newest version of Android with all the newest apps all running smoothly on really old phones! So it’s the software that in essence just goes bad after a few years, or more specifically isn’t usable with other more modern software. If you have the wherewithal to run a few commands in the terminal, you have all the skills you need to side-load an OS because people have already done all the work for you and posted the files in places like XDA developers.

Yes, for several reasons. Cost. It would be perfectly possible to engineer a phone where all the parts have been tested and are of the highest quality to ensure that it lasts for a long time. The problem is, this will cost more that one selected to the lowest common mean time to failure and this translates to lower profit per unit, or higher price per unit.Revenue. This is the obvious one. Manufacturers want to sell you multiple phones, but if you have one that lasts 10 years, then they cannot.Innovations. A difficult one, this. This is the reason that manufacturers give, they claim that to get their innovations to the public as quickly as possible, a 2-year cycle is fine, whilst releasing “new” models each year.

No. Smartphones are a special giant case of overheated consumerism. No need to “build” obsolescence in. Just keep re-designing to incorporate the latest tech from the semiconductor industry and, if you are Apple or Samsung or Lenovo (and several others), technology you’ve developed through R&D, like flexible screens and multiple cameras and OLED displays. The world will beat a path to your door to buy each annual generation. Go figure! And laugh derisively as I do when I see the queue at the Apple store each year.

The batteries have limited lives, and most new ones are designed for them to not be replaceable. This results in cleaner, more water-resistant packaging. Over time, the hardware capabilities of new phones get much better, and most vendors have very little interest in making new software compatible with old less capable phones. That’s if they have any interest in updating phones after they are sold at all, even for security reasons. The upshot is that phones are best thought of as short-lived consumables, not as “durable goods”.

No, and this has been contributing to Apple’s woes of late, making it hard for the company to maintain its growth rate. People are keeping their phones for three and four years, or passing on two year old phones to friends and relatives. There are still a lot of people using iPhone 6.

Apparently some things phones were operating slower especially after a couple of years from new, and their batteries were not holding a charge as they were supposed to be. That is the beginning of obsolescence and it’s very frustrating. It maybe that way so people believe they need to update their phones, even though the phones update regularly. Most young people like to be tech savvy and tend to want the latest phone, but a new battery and have the phone checked before spending a lot on a new one if the existing phone is fine.

No. Most smartphones are fashion items. As such they do not need to become functionally obsolete. They become outdated and people feel the need to buy a new one, even though there is no functional difference between the current phone and last year’s phone.
